timeline.message: prototype for optimizing user entries endpoint using named query
manually construct entrypath by retrieving path elements in JPQL query
Clean up, created EntryLite class to preserve types when querying from database
more clean up, removed temp endpoint

timeline.author: Ldcabansay

timeline.bodyText: Optional nitpick -- would call s instead of c.
timeline.author: coverbeck

replies.bodyText:
the c pattern is in all named queries for tools and workflows too so I just carried it over, not sure why its c though? Container?
Seems like we don't have things set up test named queries directly, the tests for postgres can only query in SQL. Denis suggested a an integration test and the existing test already calls the endpoint and checks the path generated. I could make a test using the generated sql, but that seemed a bit indirect. Open to other ideas.
replies.author: Ldcabansay

replies.bodyText:
The short name is a stand-in for the longer name, so I like it to reflect the table (or I guess in this case entity) name. I did say optional, and I don't feel too strongly about it.
If the existing integration tests validate the endpoint, I think that's fine; just wanted to make sure.
replies.author: coverbeck

replies.bodyText: The c is back from when we called tools containers, we should try to replace it when we can.
replies.author: agduncan94

timeline.author: coverbeck

timeline.bodyText: Has this changed, other than combining two lines into one? In any case, should have each NamedQuery on its own line.
timeline.author: coverbeck

replies.bodyText: its a leftover from when I tried ways that would grab all entry types through in one query
replies.author: Ldcabansay

timeline.bodyText: It looks like the only place you call this, you're passing getEntryPath() as a parameter. Since getEntryPath() is already a class method, I would get rid of the parameter and just have makePrettyPath use getEntryPath
timeline.author: coverbeck

timeline.bodyText: It seems so fast right now that it doesn't matter, but ideally you would pass count as a parameter, at least when the filter is null.
timeline.author: coverbeck

timeline.bodyText:
It was like this, but I think you can just limit on the stream:
...
.limit(count != null ? count : Integer.MAX_VALUE)
.collect(...

Optionally have a default value for count, which I think makes sense, and then you don't even have to do the null check.
timeline.author: coverbeck
coverbeck

timeline.message: limit to count in stream, other requested fixes and changes

timeline.bodyText: Is the only difference here that you put the }) on a new line? I think so, but want to make sure.
timeline.author: coverbeck
